items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message: Tides are higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. The peak high water level at Christchurch Harbour is at 11:42 PM this evening 21/08/2024 with a level of 1.24 mAOD with southwesterly force 6 winds. (mAOD is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff will be closing flood gates if necessary. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
"River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.52mAOD at 05:30 on 22/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 17 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 22/08/24, or as the situation changes."

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge and high spring tides on the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Flooding is possible between 06:30 and 08:30 tomorrow, Thursday 22/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts / warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 21:00 on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over the next 3 days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted peaks. 
Avonmouth 7.7m to 7.9m at 21:30 on 21/08/2024, and 7.5m to 7.8m at 09:45 on 22/08/2024.
Sharpness 9.9m to 10.3m at 23:30 on 21/08/2024, and 9.8m to 10.2m at 10:45 on 22/08/2024. 
Flooding is not forecast at other gauge sites. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides from Wednesday 21st August, Thursday 22nd August to Friday 23rd August. High water at Ilfracombe on Wednesday evening is at 20:15 BST. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
 
Force 6 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 130mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it;
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Wednesday evening is 5.26 mAOD, this is 0.13 metres above astronomical tide level.
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Thursday morning is 5.10 mAOD, this is 0.26 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. The first peak high water level at West Bay Harbour is at 9:00 PM this evening 21/08/24 with a level of 2.50 mAOD with southwesterly force 5 winds. Thursday mornings tide 22/08/24 will not quite reach our threshold for a flood alert,  but tomorrow evenings tide at 9:43PM will exceed threshold with a predicted level of 2.52 mAOD with southwesterly force 5 winds. Tide levels will start dropping from Friday mornings tide onwards. (mAOD is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Sea spray overtopping along the coast is possible and high water levels in the harbour are forecast. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. People in the areas should consider taking action now. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary from Liverpool and Wirral to Widnes

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024.    

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 01:00 AM on 21/08/2024 at the following location: 

Rock Park, peaking around 01:30 AM 

Hale Village, peaking around 02:00 AM. 

Flooding of property is not expected. 

We currently do not anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide tomorrow afternoon, 22/08/2024. 

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.    

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.    

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024, by 09:00 AM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued because of a series of high tides that are expected over the next 3 days with tides peaking Thursday evening 22/08/24. Conditions may apply for an hour either side of high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks.
Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 21:30 on 21/08/2024 and 7.2m to 7.5m at 09:45 on 22/08/2024.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 7.9m at 21:30 on 21/08/2024 and 7.5 to 7.8m at 09:45 on 22/08/2024. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads that may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 2pm on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
High tides and  strong winds overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss at 1:15 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3  hours either side of this time.
Further flooding is possible on the midday tide tomorrow, 22/08/2024 and into Friday 23/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss.
We have closed flood gates at St. Georges Quay, Lancaster.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening and tomorrow morning in response to high tides from 21/08/2024 at 8.30 PM along the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade. Flooding of coastal roads and foothpaths are possible, property flooding is not expected.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 8:30 PM on 21/08/2024 with a level of 7.77 mAODN with south -westerly strong breeze force 5 winds.  The second high water is at 09:00 AM on 22/08/2024 with a level of 7.68 mAODN with a south-westerly strong force 7 winds.  Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024.   

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 02:00 AM on 22/08/2024 at the following locations:   

Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 02:30 AM  

Eastford Road, peaking around 02:45 AM   

Arpley Bridge, Knutsford Road, and Howley, peaking around 03:00 AM  

It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.  

We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide tomorrow afternoon, 22/08/2024. We are also expecting the Flood Alert level to be met during the early hours of the morning on Friday, 23/08/2024, and Saturday, 24/08/2024. 

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.   

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.   

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024, by 09:00 AM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the possibility of spray overtopping on the coast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024. 

Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads from Hilbre Island and along the coast from West Kirby to Heswall from 01:00 AM 22/08/2024. Flooding of property is not expected.  

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further Flood Alerts and Flood Warnings. 

We do not currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the high tide tomorrow afternoon, 22/08/2024. 

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024, by 09:00 AM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This Flood Warning remains in force due strong winds, surge and high spring tides. Wave and spray overtopping is possible tomorrow, Thursday 22/08/2024, between 06:30 and 08:30. This could cause some localised flooding. Areas most at risk of flooding include Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the coming days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 21:00 on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge and high spring tides on the coast. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads in the Spurn Road, Southfield Farm and Kilnsea Caravan park areas. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. Flooding is possible between 6:15AM and 9:30AM tomorrow, Thursday 22/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast between 7am to 11am, tomorrow morning, 22/08/24.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4:17 mAODN at 9.00am, on Thursday 22 August 2024, which is -0.47m above tide tables, wind Force 7, South-Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Friday 23 August 2024 at 9:15 am is currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation.  We will update this message by 11 am tomorrow, Thursday 22 August.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 9:30 PM on 21/08/2024 with a level of 7.76 mAODN with south-westerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024 with a level of 7.67 mAODN with south-westerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham

High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss at 1:15 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Further flooding is possible on the midday tide tomorrow, 22/08/2024 and into Friday 23/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days
Areas most at risk include Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 1:15 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Further flooding is possible on the midday tide tomorrow, 22/08/2024 into Friday 23/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Thursday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 22/08/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong South Westerly Force 6 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.07 m. The total forecast tide is 6.10 metres Chart Datum (3.05 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Thursday afternoon's tide at 14:00 on 22/08/2024 is forecast to be 4 cm higher (3.09 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are predicted to continue each high tide until Saturday 24/08/2024. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 22/08/2024.

items.description: Coast at Barrow in Furness
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding.
The highest tide level at Barrow in Furness is expected at 1:30 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include the Coastline at Barrow in Furness.
Further flooding is possible during high tides until the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Estuary at Oldbury-on-Severn, Northwick and Avonmouth

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, Gloucestershire, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.67 mAODN at 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, with south-westerly force 7 winds.
Please note: The high tide on the evening of 21st August does not meet flood alert criteria.
Areas most at risk include the Severn Estuary at Oldbury-on-Severn, Northwick and Avonmouth including Aust and Old Passage.
No property flooding is expected.
After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled, and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides are expected due to a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge from broader weather systems over the UK. Strong winds may cause large waves within the estuary tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 4:45AM and 5:15AM, 21/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Newcastle Quayside.

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 05:15AM and 06:00AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:15AM and 07:15AM, 23/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024. Please remain vigilant for any potential flood warnings around Newcastle Quayside. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening and tomorrow morning in response to high tides at Porlock Weir.

Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir at 8:30 PM on 20/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point. The first forecast high water is at 8:30 PM on 20/08/2024 with a level of 6.41 mAODN with westerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 8:45 AM on 21/08/2024, with a level of 6.19 mAODN and south-westerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This flood alert is expected to remain in force during this high tide sequence up to and including the high tide at 22:30 on 23/08/2024. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between a 01:15 and 03:15, Thursday 22 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.71 mAODN at 02:15, Thursday 22 August, which is 0.0m above tide tables, wind Force 6, in a south westerly direction (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Thursday 22 August.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding.
The highest tide level at North Morecambe Bay is expected at 1:30 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
We expect to see similar impacts from the high tides until Saturday 24/08/2024. 
We have closed flood gates at Arnside promenade.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads in as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:30 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
High tides and strong winds may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 05:00AM and 06:00AM, 21/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The areas most likely to be affected are Newbiggin Bay North Promenade and Beadnell Harbour Road North.  

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 05:00AM and 06:45AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:45AM and 07:45AM, 23/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 23/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further Flood Alerts and Flood Warnings.  

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.  

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024, by 09:00 AM, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tides and strong winds may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 04:30AM and 05:15AM, 21/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Berwick between bridges. 

This alert is in force for the high tides Wednesday (21/08/2024) Thursday (22/08/2024) and Friday morning (23/08/2024). High tides are anticipated between 04:45AM and 06:00AM, 22/08/2024 and 05:30AM and 06:45AM, 23/08/2024.

items.description: Coast from Gretna to Silloth
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding.
The highest tide level is expected to be at Coastline from Gretna to Silloth at 1:45 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Coastline from Gretna to Silloth.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow afternoon, but we do expect to issue a further flood alert for the high tide tomorrow night. 
We have closed flood gates at Skinburness Marsh.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Silloth of 6.11 mAODN at 1:45 AM on 22/08/2024 (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening in response to a high tide on 21/08/2024 at 8.00 PM at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point. The forecast high water is at 8:00 PM on 21/08/2024 with a level of 6.77 mAODN with southerly moderate breeze force 4 winds. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

We will be monitoring the high tide and closing gates at Brean and Weston-super-Mare as required.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary at Brockweir
items.message:
A flood warning has been issued as a series of high tides are expected over the next 3 days with tides peaking this Thursday evening 22/08/2024. High Tides may impact properties and roads including garages at Brockweir. 
Predicted peaks.
Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 21:30 on 21/08/2024 and 7.2m to 7.5m at 09:45 on 22/08/2024.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 7.9m at 21:30 on 21/08/2024 and 7.5 to 7.8m at 09:45 on 22/08/2024. 
   
levels are rising and conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Lancashire coastline at Sunderland, around Sunderland Point, Bazil Point and Potts Corner
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves are expected to cause flooding overnight.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Lancaster Road from Oxcliffe Hill Farm to Heaton Bottom Road, Heaton and Bazil Point. Sunderland Brows Farm, Sunderland Point, First and Second Terrace, Alderley Bank, Potts Corner and Shorefields House and Caravan Park at 1:30 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Lancaster Road from Oxcliffe Hill Farm to Heaton Bottom Road, Heaton and Bazil Point. Sunderland Brows Farm, Sunderland Point, First and Second Terrace, Alderley Bank, Potts Corner and Shorefields House and Caravan Park.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow afternoon.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Consider activating any property flood protection products in these areas.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads in these areas as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message:

The highest tide level from Silloth to St Bees Head is expected at 1:45 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas along the coast from Silloth to St Bees Head including Allonby, Maryport, Flimby, Workington, Parton and Whitehaven.
Further flooding is possible tomorrow afternoon due to higher than normal tides combined with strong winds and large waves.
We have closed flood gates at Flimby and Well Lane Maryport.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

We do not expect to issue further Flood Warnings for the high tides tomorrow but we do expect to issue a Flood Alert for the high tide tomorrow night. 
We have closed flood gates at Skinburness Marsh.

This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert remains in force due to high tides and surge on the coast. Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Flooding of coastal roads is possible between 19:30 and21:45, today, Wednesday 21/08/2024 and tomorrow between 05:15 and 09:15. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 21:00 on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
We are expecting rain between 16:00pm and 23:00pm today 21/08/2024.  This will be followed by a brief dry spell.  A heavier band of rain is then expected between 03:00am and 11:00am on Thursday 22/08/2024.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible from 05:30am, property flooding is not expected.  More rain is expected overnight Thursday until Friday lunchtime.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge and high spring tides on the coast. Flooding is possible from tomorrow, Thursday 22/08/2024 between 08:00AM and 11:15AM. Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Estuary at Severn Beach
items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.67 mAODN at 10:00 AM on 22/08/2024, with south-westerly force 7 winds.
Please note: The high tide on the evening of 21st August does not meet flood alert criteria.
Areas most at risk include the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning.
No property flooding is expected.
After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea from New Brighton to Hoylake
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the possibility of spray overtopping on the coast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024. 

Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads from 01:00 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding of property is not expected. 

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further Flood Alerts and Flood Warnings. 

We do not currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the high tide tomorrow afternoon, 22/08/2024. 

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.   

Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/08/2024, by 09:00 AM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Fleetwood to Blackpool
items.message:

Areas most at risk include Fleetwood, Larkholme, Broadwater, Cleveleys, Rossall Beach, Anchorsholme, Blackpool and Revoe.
Further flooding is possible throughout the morning due to higher than normal tides combined with strong south-westerly winds and large onshore waves.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads in these areas as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tides of Wednesday 21 August and Thursday 22 August. 
High water at Falmouth is at 7.30pm on Wednesday and 8.12pm on Thursday, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 5 south westerly winds are forecast to cause flooding of waterside locations and roads.  
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn, Flushing, Mylor Bridge, the A39 at Perranarworthal, Devoran, Calenick, Truro and the A390 at Tresillian.
The tidal gates at Flushing will be closed.
Do not walk or drive through flood water.  
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 12pm on Thursday 22 August, or earlier if the situation changes. 
Detailed tidal information:
Wednesday: Forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.60m AOD.  
Thursday: Forecast high tide level at Falmouth is 2.64m AOD. 
Expect tide levels along to coast to be between 60mm - 70mm above tide table level.

items.description: Cumbrian coastline from St Bees Head to Haverigg, along the coast from North Head to Haverigg
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves are expected to cause flooding overnight.
The highest tide level is expected at 1:30 AM on 22/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include beachfront properties at Coulderton, Nethertown and Braystones. Low lying properties at Saltcoats, Ravenglass, A595 at Muncaster Mill Bridge and the Esk Estuary.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow.
We have closed flood gates at Ravenglass.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 22/08/2024, or as the situation changes.
